metadata.title: Green synthesis of hydrolyzed starch–chitosan nano-composite as drug delivery system to gram negative bacteria

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Environmental Nanotechnology, Monitoring & Management
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/enmm
Green synthesis of hydrolyzed starch–chitosan nano-composite as drug delivery system to gram negative bacteria
Amr Shehabeldinea, Mohamed Hasaninb,⁎
a Botanyand Microbiology Department, Faculty of Science (Boys), Al-Azhar University, 11651, Cairo, Egypt b Cellulose and Paper Department, National Research Centre, 12622, Dokki, Cairo, Egypt
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Drug release Starch Chitosan Nano-composite
A B S T R A C T
The objective of this study was to investigate the improvement of Ciprofloxacin hydrochloride (CIP) activity by incorporation into green based nano-composite and control the antibiotic release to increase its bioavailability. Microbial glycoside hydrolases support the enzymatic processing of starch to obtain hydrolyzed starch. Synthesis of hydrolyzed starch/chitosan loaded with CIP (HS/Ch-NC) was carried out via the green ecofriendly method. Characterization analyses of prepared nano-composite were included fourier transform Infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), thermal analysis (TGA and DTGA), dynamic light scattering (DLS), scanning electron microscope(SEM), mapping and transmission electron microscope (TEM) approved the synthesis of composite in nano-scale in spherical shape with average particle size 291 nm. In vitro drug release study of nano-composite HS/Ch-NC showed a rapid initial release rate was about 86% within 20 h. HS/Ch-NC showed high activity against gram negative bacterial strains due to the successful released of CIP from the HS/Ch-NC into the tested bacterial strains with the lowest concentration, 62.5 and 125 μg/ml for Enterobacter aerogenes and Pseudomonas aeruginosa respectively. Additionally, the minimum bactericidal concentration (MBC)/minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) ratio was observed that the HS/Ch-NC has bacteriostatic effect toward two tested organisms.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Over the past few years, increasing antibiotic resistance among human pathogens necessitates developing new antibiotics or new drug formulations to overcome these problems (Stewart and Costerton, 2001). Many human pathogens are conventional in secondary infections with acute effect pathogenicity especially in immunosuppressed patients. Otherwise, the long-term antibiotics treatment in these pataints is injurious (Borody et al., 2003). Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Enterobacter aerogenes are the most common human pathogens that cause nosocomial infections with high drug resistance behavior (Velusamy et al., 2016). Nanotechnology has undergone marge different fields including pharmaceuticals, microbiology, infectious diseases and materials science to solve the drug resistance phenomena via nano-composite materials systems (Abdelraof et al., 2019a,b; Bergemann et al., 1999, Hasanin2019a,b; Seil and Webster, 2012; Vellingiri et al., 2013). Moreover, the nano-composites from natural biopolymers origen have high safety profile and it can help in biocompatibility enhancing. Additionally, the controlled drug release systems have many advantages as reduction in dosing frequency and enhanced patient compliance as well as improve the bioavailability
which refers to the degree and rate at which an administered drug is absorbed by the body's circulatory system (Heaney, 2001; Puri et al., 2015). Recently, the composition between the different groups of polysaccharides gives broad characteristics in drug release and carrier systems (Lo et al., 2007; Moghannem et al., 2018). In context, amylose which considered as polysaccharide used as a biomaterial carrier to rifampicin in drug control release system against Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Ribeiro et al., 2017). Besides, chitosan is one of the most popular polysaccharide has attracted increased interest due to its extensive application in controlled drug release systems of various therapeutic uses (Vivek et al., 2014). Also, it possess unique characteristics that hold promise in terms of efficacy as drug carriers, with improved drug solubility, stability, bioavailability, and reduced drug toxicity (Nagpal et al., 2013) as well as it possesses many unique properties, including antimicrobial characteristics (Jiang et al., 2010). On the other hand, starch is natural polysaccharide which considered of versatile materials for potential use in polymer technology (Cañigueral et al., 2009; El-Abd et al., 2017). In context, the starch is inexpensive price and a sustainable natural biopolymer (Belhassen et al., 2009). Starch and chitosan are naturally abundant polysaccharides which are generally non-toxic, available from renewable sources, and suitable for film

formation as well as their can be used as food with high safety profile (Bourtoom and Chinnan, 2008; Xu et al., 2005). Although starch is cheap and easily biodegradable, it is very sensitive to moisture and exhibits poor mechanical properties e.g. Young`s modulus, tensile strength and elongation (Whistler and Daniel, 2000). The blending of starch and chitosan is an alternative way to not only improve the mechanical and water vapor barrier properties, as well as the antimicrobial attributesof starch film but also to reduce the cost and enhance the biodegradability of chitosan film (Bourtoom and Chinnan, 2008). Ciprofloxacin has been proven to be effective against various pathogens that cause clinically common infectious diseases such as chronic osteomyelitis. It is most widely used for bacterial bone infection for most of the Gram negative pathogens bacteria (Maleki Dizaj et al., 2017). Therefore, in the present work, microbial hydrolyzed starch and chitosan are loaded with Ciprofloxacin were prepared by ionic exchange method to improve the drug efficacy and to prolong the acting time of the drug via the prolonged release.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text: Chitosan (Ch) used in this study was purchased from Sigma Aldrich (St. Louis, and molecular weight 650,000) and include low molar mass CS (LCS) (viscosity, 275.9 cps, degree of deacetylation, 85.5%), Soluble starch, and Ciprofloxacin hydrochloride were purchased from Sigma Chemical Co. as well as other chemicals, culture media and reagents used in this study were of analytical grade.

sections.heading: 2.2.1. Biological preparation of hydrolyzed starch (HS)
sections.text: Enzymatic hydrolysis of starch was carried out to reducing the particle size and increase the solubility of starch as well as activation of its surface by microbial hydrolysis according to Kim et al. (2008). Bacterial strain previously isolated, identified, and stored in our laboratory were screened for amylase production in starch agar medium (Desouky et al., 2014). After 48 h, incubation plates were flooded with Gram's iodine solution to observe a clear zone that was an indication of starch hydrolysis. Bacillus thuringiensis KJ206079 was selected based on the large clear zone for further study. Microbial amylases obtained from bacteria (Bacillus thuringiensis KJ206079) (Desouky et al., 2014), bacterial culture was incubated at 37 °C for up to 24 h with shaking at 150 rpm in the presence of starch as substrate, then absolute Ethanol was added to inactivate the enzyme and the hydrolyzed starch was collected by centrifuging the solution at 2280× g for 10min. The starch residue (1 g, dry basis) was dispersed with 50% ethanol (300mL×3 times) and then dried at 45 °C in the oven overnight. The dispersion was stored in a refrigerator (4 °C) for 1 h and then ultrasonicated for up to 420 s (frequency 20 kHz, output power 300W, Ultrasonic homogenizer UH-600, SMT, Japan) in an ice bath. The starch was then washed three times with 50% ethanol (50mL) and once with 95% ethanol (50mL) before drying (40 °C, 24 h).

sections.heading: 2.2.2. Preparation hydrolyzed starch/chitosan loaded with ciprofloxacin
sections.text: The nano-composite was prepared with dissolved 0.5 g of HS in 1% (w/v) chitosan solution. The reaction mixture was stirring at 1500 rpm for overnight at 70OC. Ciprofloxacin hydrochloride (0.1 g) was dissolved in a prepared mixture under the same stirring condition. During the addition of the antibiotic the temperature is kept at 0 °C in dark for overnight. The prepared HS/Ch-NC kept frozen in dark for further investigations.

sections.heading: 2.2.3. In vitro antibiotic release
sections.text:
In vitro drug release study was carried out in two different pH values of 1.5(referred to the stomach) and 7.4 (referred to the blood) in
phosphate buffer solution (PBS). Drug-loaded nano-composite, suspended in 5.0 ml PBS in the dialysis membrane (cutoff: 12 kDa, Sigma Aldrich) tied at both ends and immersed in 100ml of PBS then put into shaker incubator under the condition of 37 °C and 25 rpm (Ji et al., 2011). To determine the concentration of drug in the receiving compartment, samples (5 ml) were withdrawn at scheduled time points and replaced by the same volume of fresh pre-warmed PBS solution to avoid saturation phenomena and maintain the sink condition. Samples were analyzed at 270 nm UV/Vis spectrophotometer (Jasco V-630). The release dosage at each moment was calculated and drawn into the cumulative release curve.
2.2.4. Characterizations of hydrolyzed starch/chitosan loaded with ciprofloxacin
The structure and intermolecular structure were investigated via different instruments techniques. FTIR The structural changes were studied using FTIR spectrometer JASCO 6100 spectrometer, Japan using KBr discs in the range of 4000–400 cm−1. Transmission electron microscope TEM, Model JEM2010, Japan, was used to investigate particle size and morphology of the synthesized HS/Ch-NC. SEM and EXD Analyses The morphology and topography of the prepared samples were analyzed by (SEM, Quanta FEG 250, FEI) attached with the EDX Unit, with accelerating voltage 30 K. To prepare the SEM sample, a thin layer of Au was coated onto the sample by sputtering coating unit. The thermal behavior of HS/Ch-NC and its precursor were determined by TGA The thermal analysis was carried out using TGAQ500 device. DLS The particle size distribution and zeta potential of the prepared samples were measured, using Nicomp™ 380 ZLS size analyzer, USA. Leaser light scattering was used at 170ᵒ in case of particle size detection where zeta potential was measured at18ᵒ.

sections.heading: 2.2.5.1. Antibacterial activity of HS/Ch-NC by agar disk
sections.text:
method. Enterobacter aerogenes MTCC111 and Pseudomonas aeruginosaMTCC1034 were obtained from Microbial Type Culture Collection (MTCC) IMTECH, Chandigarh MediMark® Europe, 11 rue Emile ZOLA B.P.2332, FRANCE. An antibacterial activity test was carried out using the agar disk method (Takasaka et al., 2017). To perform this assay, sterilized filter paper disks 6mm were placed on Mueller–Hinton agar plates which were already swabbed with test bacteria (McFarland turbidity of 0.5). Paper discs were loaded with 30 μg of HS, Ch., CIP and HS/Ch-NC loaded with ciprofloxacin then incubated at 37 °C for 24 h. After the incubation period, the diameters inhibition (DI) the including diameter of the paper disc (mm) was measured by using a Vernier caliper. The measurement was done in triplicate for each sample.
2.2.5.2. Determination of minimum inhibitory concentration. Resazurin is
an oxidation-reduction indicator used for the evaluation of cell growth (Zheng et al., 2019). It is a blue and non-toxic dye that becomes pink when reduced to resorufin by oxidoreductases within viable cells. Bacterial suspension with standard turbidity of 0.5 Mc Farland was prepared from the liquid culture (Mueller–Hinton broth). Finally, the micro-dilution plate was incubated at 37 °C for 24 h and the color change was then assessed visually (Zheng et al., 2019). To each well 10 μl of resazurin indicator solution was added, any color changes from purple to pink or colorless were recorded as positive. The lowest concentration in which color change occurred was taken as the MIC value. MBC value was determinate by sub-culturing bacteria from broth dilution MIC test (unchanged color) into Mueller–Hinton plates at 37 °C for 24 h. MBC was detected by the lowest concentration resulted from
the inhibition of the growth on the agar plates (Moon, 2018). The action of HS/Ch-NC as antibacterial activity on selected bacteria can be described by the ratio of MBC/MIC. When the ratio equals to 1 or 2, it means bactericidal effect, and when the ratio is ≥4 or 16 it means, bacteriostatic effects (Moon, 2018).

sections.heading: 3.1.1. FT-IR analysis
sections.text:
The Combination between biodegradable biopolymers and drugs plays an important role in improving the drug therapeutic potential and
bioavailability as well as upgrading its release profile. FT-IR is a useful tool to understand the structural changes due to the interaction between the constituents of nano-composite. Fig. 1 illustrated the FTIR spectra of HS/Ch-NC, Ch, HS and CIP. Antibiotic spectrum clarified many intense bands at 3493, 2950, 1700, 1624 and 1045 cm−1 were assigned the stretching vibration of −OH (intermolecular hydrogen bonding), alkenes and aromatic C–H stretching, C]O stretching, C]N stretching vibration and C–F stretching respectively (Sahoo et al., 2012, 2011). Moreover, the chitosan spectrum exhibited various characteristic peaks located at 3434, 2994, 1655 1312 and 1023 cm−1 which were assigned to −OH stretching, C–H stretching vibration, acetylated amino groups, C]N stretching and CeOeC stretching vibration, respectively (Gomes et al., 2008; Shaheen et al., 2019).
The FTIR spectrum of starch showed the characteristic functional groups 3435, 2930 and 1644 which were attributed to the stretching
vibration of −OH, C–H and absorbed water respectively. The IR bands at 1134 and 1023 cm−1 were assigned to the stretching vibration associated with CeOeC on starch chain (Li et al., 2019). On the other hand, HS/Ch-NC spectrum showed the main features of Ch spectrum as well as some peaks of HS spectrum; mainly in the range (1250–1065 cm−1). No significant changes recorded in the functional groups in loaded HS/Ch-NC toward CIP. These results indicated that no new chemical bonds were formed between these functional groups in drug and nano-composite. It was believed that CIP was trapped within HS/Ch-NC and hence it cannot be detected its peaks in the nano-composite FTIR spectrum and the results confirmed that the drug is physically dispersed in the HS/Ch-NC and it may be released as wild type.

sections.heading: 3.1.2. Thermal analysis
sections.text:
Thermal stability is an important character that must be labeled the
drug carriers system as well as it conform to the usability of these systems. TGA and DTGA were used to evaluate the HS/Ch-NC and it started materials thermal behaviors. Fig. 2 showed the TGA and DTGA spectra of the tested materials. Fig. 2a and b cleared the thermal analysis data of the tested samples. HS/Ch-NC recorded high ΔT (250 °C) in compare with its started material. On the other hand, the weight loss percent of HS/Ch-NC was higher than all tested samples except chitosan. However, the weight loss percent of chitosan was recorded 51% at maximum peak temperature (Tp 242 °C) and HS/Ch-NC recorded 49% at Tp 471 °C. Hence, the weight loss percent of HS/Ch-NC is recorded at temperature equal double value in comparison with chitosan. Overall above data were confirmed that the HS/Ch-NC showed the highest thermal stability in comparison with the CIP, Ch and HS.

sections.heading: 3.1.3. DLS analysis
sections.text: Dynamic light scattering is the advanced tools in which the particle size distribution as well as zeta potential measurements are tested. Fig. 2c illustrated the particle size distribution of HS/Ch-NC. The particle appeared uniformed distribution with the bell shape. The DLS data were cleared that the PDI value of HS/Ch-NC is more close to 1.0 than others according to Gaussian distribution law (Hasanin et al., 2019a,b; Ibrahim et al., 2018). Hence, the HS/Ch-NC is homogenous as well as in nano-size with average particle size 291 nm. Moreover, zeta potential measurements supported the particle size data where the average zeta potential value of HS/Ch-NCis 58.37mV. These results have approved the stability of the HS/Ch-NCin its solutions as reported in the previous studies (Guo et al., 2015).

sections.heading: 3.1.4. Topography analysis
sections.text:
Fig. 3 showed the topography analysis of HS/Ch-NC included the TEM and SEM. TEM topography in Fig. 3a cleared that the HS/Ch-NC was found in nano-scale with homogenous particle distribution as
confirmed with the histogram in Fig. 3b this result was in good agreement with the DLS data (Jain and Banerjee, 2008). The selected area electron diffraction (SAED) Fig. 3c showed high crystallinity degree of the HS/Ch-NC (Hasanin et al., 2019a,b). Fig. 3c showed the SEM topography which appeared sponge like form this emphasized that the HS/Ch-NC was trapped the CIP into the network which prepared as result to the composition process and release slowly under control these results were emphasized the FT-IR conclusion. Moreover, Fig. 4e cleared the mapping graph which emphasized that the CIP was homogenously distributed into HS/Ch-NC network according to fluoride atom distribution. Additionally, EDX was conformed that the structure of composite to the composition at the atomic level as well as appeared of fluoride atom which emphasized the presence of CIP trapped into HS/Ch-NC.

sections.heading: 3.2.1. Disk diffusion method
sections.text: In vitro antibacterial activities of the synthesized HS/Ch-NC were performed against Enterobacter aerogenes MTCC111 and Pseudomonas aeruginosa MTCC1034 by disk diffusion assays. The diameter of the inhibition zone (DI) for the CIP, CS, HS, and HS/Ch-NC was summarized in Table 1 and illustrated in Fig. 4a and b. No antibacterial activity was observed with hydrolyzed starch against both bacterial strains. Chitosan showed less inhibitory zone against Enterobacter aerogenes comparing with Pseudomonas aeruginosa. The polycationic chitosan charge is associated with the degree of deacetylation. Higher positive charge density leads to strong electrostatic interaction which is an important factor for antibacterial activity (Takahashi et al., 2008). Chitosan binds to the negatively charged bacterial surface and originates agglutination, or an increase of permeability of the microbial wall, that eventually provokes a release of the intracellular components (Helander et al., 2001). It can inhibit mRNA and protein synthesis by binding to the microbial DNA (Takahashi et al., 2008). HS/Ch-NC was the most effective substance retarding microbial growth of all tested pathogenic bacteria at concentration of 1000 μg/ml this may be due to the effect of synergisty.

sections.heading: 3.2.2. Determination of minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC)
sections.text:
Besides, the DI and MIC data were correlated well, the higher DI observed with lower MIC values proved good antibacterial activity for Ch, HS, HS/Ch-NC and CIP was tested against Gram negative (Enterobacteraer aerogenes and Pseudomonas aeruginosa) bacterial strains
Data are expressed in mean± SD (n = 3).
using resazurin mediated microtiter plate assay (RMPA). The advantages of this assay over other antibacterial assays include increased sensitivity for small quantities of sample, ability to distinguish between bacteriostatic and bactericidal effects and also quantitative determination of MIC (Langfield et al., 2004). The inhibitory activity of HS, Ch,
HS/Ch-NC and CIP was examined visually by the color change of the resazurin indicator. The color change observed at various concentrations of HS, Ch, HS/Ch.NC and CIP were shown in Fig. 5. HS has not showed any color change for all the bacterial strains, which indicates that HS exhibited no inhibitory activity against all the strains. Chitosan
MIC: minimum inhibitory concentration, MBC: minimum bactericidal concentration, Bactericidal (+) =≤2 Bacteriostatic (−) =≥4.
has shown moderate antibacterial activity against both the Gram-negative bacteria (Fig. 5). HS/Ch-NC has shown enhanced antibacterial activity against Enterobacteraer aerogenes more than Pseudomonas aeruginosa (Fig. 5). The enhanced activity was due to the HS, which acts as a stabilizing agent and also acts as a carrier for the Ch. and CIP. Also, this could be due to a polycationic property of HS/Ch-NC with greater surface area and positive surface charge density that enables improved reaction with negatively charged bacterial cell membranes leading to altered cell permeability. The possible antibacterial mechanisms were gain from synergetic effect between the inhibiting DNA gyrase (CIP) (Bearden and Danziger, 2001; Kohanski et al., 2010) and polycationic nature of chitosan which enhanced by converting into nano-sized (Fouad, 2008) leading the bacterial death (Kohanski et al., 2010; Qi et al., 2004).
MIC and MBC values for HS, Ch. and HS/Ch-NC and CIP were listed in Table 2. HS/Ch-NC exhibit the highest activity with the lowest concentration, it was 62.5 and 125 μg/ml for Enterobacter aerogenesand Pseudomonas aeruginosa respectively. The experiments confirm that the bacterial strains are more sensitive towards HS/Ch-NC when comparing with CIP as a positive control. Table 2 also shows MBC/MIC ratio for chitosan and HS/Ch-NC which compared with CIP against Enterobacter aerogenes and Pseudomonas aeruginosa. The action of CIP and chitosan on both selected microorganisms was bactericidal with MBC/MIC ratio was 2, while the action of prepared composite was bacteriostatic on Enterobacter aerogenes and Pseudomonas aeruginosa with MBC/MIC ratio 4 and 8 respectively.

sections.heading: 3.2.3. In vitro release studies of HS/Ch-NC
sections.text: The relationship between the cumulative release of CIP and time was demonstrated in Fig. 6. In vitro drug release profile of HS/Ch.-NCat (pH 1.5 and PBS 7.5) medium at different time intervals (0, 2, 4, 6, 8, 10 and 24 h) was studied. The release profiles of the CIP from HS/ChNC in PBS buffer showed slow release ranging from 4 to 12 h, which releases about 33% of the drug. While In the case of drug release profile in HCl, the highest release rate of 86% was achieved within 20 h this may be as a result of Ch structure break down at lower pH, which leads to drug release in the medium.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
The combination between two exhibited biopolymer and loaded with promising antibiotic is amplified the antibiotic behavior as well as offered the antibiotic for a long time in compared with the free one. Moreover, the designed loading system is economic, biodegradable, bioactive, multifunction and biocompatible. Besides, the prepared HS/
Ch-NC improves both antimicrobial behaviors as well as the release dug during treatment of the pathogens. In vitro release study describes that highest drug release rate 86% was achieved within 20 h where it was found that at pH 1.5 compared with drug release rate 33% at pH 7.5. The release of CIP from HS/Ch-NC was found to be structurally intact as well as effective in its ability to inhibit the gram negative bacterial strains (Enterobacter aerogenesand Pseudomonas aeruginosa) with a higher diameter of inhibition zone and lowest MIC as compared to reference antibiotics (CIP).

metadata.abstractText: The objective of this study was to investigate the improvement of Ciprofloxacin hydrochloride (CIP) activity by incorporation into green based nano-composite and control the antibiotic release to increase its bioavailability. Microbial glycoside hydrolases support the enzymatic processing of starch to obtain hydrolyzed starch. Synthesis of hydrolyzed starch/chitosan loaded with CIP (HS/Ch-NC) was carried out via the green ecofriendly method. Characterization analyses of prepared nano-composite were included fourier transform Infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), thermal analysis (TGA and DTGA), dynamic light scattering (DLS), scanning electron microscope(SEM), mapping and transmission electron microscope (TEM) approved the synthesis of composite in nano-scale in spherical shape with average particle size 291 nm. In vitro drug release study of nano-composite HS/Ch-NC showed a rapid initial release rate was about 86% within 20 h. HS/Ch-NC showed high activity against gram negative bacterial strains due to the successful released of CIP from the HS/Ch-NC into the tested bacterial strains with the lowest concentration, 62.5 and 125 μg/ml for Enterobacter aerogenes and Pseudomonas aeruginosa respectively. Additionally, the minimum bactericidal concentration (MBC)/minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) ratio was observed that the HS/Ch-NC has bacteriostatic effect toward two tested organisms.
